bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to J. W. W. Stephens, October 12, 1928

div1.p: Carter explains the collaborative work she and Frost are doing to edit Henry Rose Carter's manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever and asks for Stephens' assistance with some references for the book.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to J. W. W. Stephens, October 12, 1928
div1.opener:
Book, Bibliography
J.W.W. Stevens
Division
///////
-----------------------------------
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
October 12, 1928.
Dear Doctor Stephens:
div1.p:
It seems far more than four years ago when my Father, the
late Assistant Surgeon General Henry Rose Carter, and myself had
the pleasure of meeting you at the International Health Conference
at Kingston, Jamaica.

Father's last illness began just three days after he had
completed that Section of his projected History of Yellow Fever
dealing with the probable place of origin of the disease. This,
as he probably told you, he believed was the West Coast of Africa.
Preceeding the Section mentioned above were two other Sections, of
which that on Epidemiology was carried up to, and inclusive of,
July 1925.

It is in regard to the bibliography of the Section on Epidemio-
logy that I am writing you now: To ask if you will be so very kind
as to give me any data you may have as to the enclosed references.
Those re (1) Aëdes (Stegomyia) aegypti breeding in crab holes at
Grand Bassam (1922)? and in (2) in mud holes and tracks of children
children
-2-
around the lagoon at Salt Pond (1923) are from unpublished re-
ports, while the fact that the matter was under further investigation is
mentioned, on page 8, as having been stated in a personal communi-
cation by yourself. 1924). I feel quite sure, however, that these obser-
vations must have been subsequently published, probably by yourself,
and shall be greatly indebted to you if you could tell me where to
find them. Naturally, I have already made as thorough a search as
was possible of the periodicals and books in the Library of the Sur-
geon General of the Army, especially those published in Great Britain,
before troubling you. The book will soon be ready to go to press,
however, and I do want those references for the bibliography, on which
I have been working “against time” for the past year. I know you
will be interested to hear that the final editing of the book is be-
ing done by Dr. Wade Hampton Frost of the Johns Hopkins School of
Hygiene and Public Health, whom Father not only loved personally, but
considered ourthe foremost American epidemiologist. Indeed, it was a great com-
fort to Father in his last illness to know that Dr. Frost would do
this work in his stead.

With highest esteem, and trusting some day to have the prive-
ledge of again seeing you, I remain
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, Dr. J. W. W. Stevens, F. R. S., Professor of Tropical Medicine,
University of Liverpool, Liverpool, England.
Enclosure.
